segment.source: On-premises deployment (Surface Hub)
segment.target: On-premises deployment (Surface Hub)

segment.source: This topic explains how you add a device account for your Microsoft Surface Hub when you have a single-forest, on-premises deployment.
segment.target: This topic explains how you add a device account for your Microsoft Surface Hub when you have a single-forest, on-premises deployment.

segment.source: On-premises deployment (Surface Hub)
segment.target: On-premises deployment (Surface Hub)

segment.source: This topic explains how you add a device account for your Microsoft Surface Hub when you have a single-forest, on-premises deployment.
segment.target: This topic explains how you add a device account for your Microsoft Surface Hub when you have a single-forest, on-premises deployment.

segment.source: If you have a single-forest on-premises deployment with Microsoft Exchange 2013 or later and Skype for Business 2013 or later, then you can use the provided PowerShell scripts to create device accounts.
segment.target: If you have a single-forest on-premises deployment with Microsoft Exchange 2013 or later and Skype for Business 2013 or later, then you can use the provided PowerShell scripts to create device accounts.

segment.source: If you’re using a multi-forest deployment, or are using Exchange 2010 or Lync 2010, you can use equivalent cmdlets that will produce the same results.
segment.target: If you’re using a multi-forest deployment, or are using Exchange 2010 or Lync 2010, you can use equivalent cmdlets that will produce the same results.

segment.source: Those cmdlets are described in this section.
segment.target: Those cmdlets are described in this section.

segment.source: Start a remote PowerShell session from a PC and connect to Exchange.
segment.target: Start a remote PowerShell session from a PC and connect to Exchange.

segment.source: Be sure you have the right permissions set to run the associated cmdlets.
segment.target: Be sure you have the right permissions set to run the associated cmdlets.

segment.source: Note here that is the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your Exchange server, and is the FQDN of your Skype for Business server.
segment.target: Note here that is the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your Exchange server, and is the FQDN of your Skype for Business server.

segment.source: After establishing a session, you’ll either create a new mailbox and enable it as a RoomMailboxAccount, or change the settings for an existing room mailbox.
segment.target: After establishing a session, you’ll either create a new mailbox and enable it as a RoomMailboxAccount, or change the settings for an existing room mailbox.

segment.source: This will allow the account to authenticate into the Surface Hub.
segment.target: This will allow the account to authenticate into the Surface Hub.

segment.source: If you're changing an existing resource mailbox:
segment.target: If you're changing an existing resource mailbox:

segment.source: If you’re creating a new resource mailbox:
segment.target: If you’re creating a new resource mailbox:

segment.source: After setting up the mailbox, you will need to either create a new Exchange ActiveSync policy, or use a compatible existing policy.
segment.target: After setting up the mailbox, you will need to either create a new Exchange ActiveSync policy, or use a compatible existing policy.

segment.source: Surface Hubs are only compatible with device accounts that have an ActiveSync policy where the PasswordEnabled property is set to False.
segment.target: Surface Hubs are only compatible with device accounts that have an ActiveSync policy where the PasswordEnabled property is set to False.

segment.source: If this isn’t set properly, then Exchange services on the Surface Hub (mail, calendar, and joining meetings), will not be enabled.
segment.target: If this isn’t set properly, then Exchange services on the Surface Hub (mail, calendar, and joining meetings), will not be enabled.

segment.source: If you haven’t created a compatible policy yet, use the following cmdlet—this one creates a policy called "Surface Hubs".
segment.target: If you haven’t created a compatible policy yet, use the following cmdlet—this one creates a policy called "Surface Hubs".

segment.source: Once it’s created, you can apply the same policy to other device accounts.
segment.target: Once it’s created, you can apply the same policy to other device accounts.

segment.source: Once you have a compatible policy, then you will need to apply the policy to the device account.
segment.target: Once you have a compatible policy, then you will need to apply the policy to the device account.

segment.source: However, policies can only be applied to user accounts and not resource mailboxes.
segment.target: However, policies can only be applied to user accounts and not resource mailboxes.

segment.source: You need to convert the mailbox into a user type, apply the policy, and then convert it back into a mailbox—you may need to re-enable it and set the password again too.
segment.target: You need to convert the mailbox into a user type, apply the policy, and then convert it back into a mailbox—you may need to re-enable it and set the password again too.

segment.source: Various Exchange properties can be set on the device account to improve the meeting experience for people.
segment.target: Various Exchange properties can be set on the device account to improve the meeting experience for people.

segment.source: You can see which properties need to be set in the Exchange properties section.
segment.target: You can see which properties need to be set in the Exchange properties section.

segment.source: If you decide to have the password not expire, you can set that with PowerShell cmdlets too.
segment.target: If you decide to have the password not expire, you can set that with PowerShell cmdlets too.

segment.source: See Password management for more information.
segment.target: See Password management for more information.

segment.source: Enable the account in Active Directory so it will authenticate to the Surface Hub.
segment.target: Enable the account in Active Directory so it will authenticate to the Surface Hub.

segment.source: Enable the device account with Skype for Business by enabling your Surface Hub AD account on a Skype for Business Server pool:
segment.target: Enable the device account with Skype for Business by enabling your Surface Hub AD account on a Skype for Business Server pool:

segment.source: You'll need to use the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) address and domain controller for the Surface Hub, along with your own Skype for Business Server pool identifier and user identity.
segment.target: You'll need to use the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) address and domain controller for the Surface Hub, along with your own Skype for Business Server pool identifier and user identity.

segment.source: OPTIONAL: You can also allow your Surface Hub to make and receive public switched telephone network (PSTN) phone calls by enabling Enterprise Voice for your account.
segment.target: OPTIONAL: You can also allow your Surface Hub to make and receive public switched telephone network (PSTN) phone calls by enabling Enterprise Voice for your account.

segment.source: Enterprise Voice isn't a requirement for Surface Hub, but if you want PSTN dialing functionality for the Surface Hub client, here's how to enable it:
segment.target: Enterprise Voice isn't a requirement for Surface Hub, but if you want PSTN dialing functionality for the Surface Hub client, here's how to enable it:

segment.source: Again, you'll need to replace the provided domain controller and phone number examples with your own information.
segment.target: Again, you'll need to replace the provided domain controller and phone number examples with your own information.

segment.source: The parameter value stays the same.
segment.target: The parameter value stays the same.
